To my friends and countrymen:

Having been urged from many quarters to set down the memories of my life as well as the events of the year ’48, insofar as they touched me personally, and to publish these recollections, I hereby fulfill the wish of my friends and ask only your kind indulgence if my descriptions lack elegance. Well then, I will do the best I can.

Once upon a time, many, many years ago, in the old city of Zerbst, in the beautiful land of Anhalt in the German homeland, a sturdy boy was born to an honest carpenter and his good wife. This boy was later baptized in the Reformed church and received the name August. Now, I cannot honestly remember all the details; only this much was clear to me: that I must be August. The boy grew up; he relished food and drink; and when, in his youthful way, he committed foolish pranks, he often received quite sensible reminders from his father or his mother.

At six, I was sent to a so‑called “Winkel School” (a small corner school) run by an old cantor’s widow named Dürre, assisted by her already well‑grown daughter, Auguste. Later, when the City Council of Zerbst had a grand, stately building erected and designated it a public school, all school‑aged children, from five to fourteen, were to attend it, and the Winkel School ceased operation. At the entrance examination I received a report: “Accepted into first grade on a trial basis!” I went there for the next five years and, in the last two, I was the top student.

In 1844 I was confirmed, and now it was time to choose a profession for life. I would have loved to become a fur tanner; however, I was unable to find a master to take me on. In 1842 I had begun working with my mother’s brother, who was a master in the fur‑tanning trade, helping there in my free hours when I was not in school. I had first to be confirmed, but before that could happen, he died; and since I could not find another master, though I tried very hard, I began an apprenticeship with Franz Wiegand, the best cabinetmaker around. The apprenticeship lasted four years.
